settings.heading: Using HSA/FSA Funds for Birth Doula Services: A Viable Option for Financially Accessible Care

settings.text: Discover the Path to Affordable and Accessible Doula Care: Leveraging IRS-Approved HSA/FSA Payments for Personalized Prenatal Education, Intervention Reduction, and More!

settings.heading: How to Utilize HSA/FSA Funds for Pregnancy Support

settings.text:
Did you know that utilizing funds from your Health Savings Account (HSA) or Flexible Spending Account (FSA) is a viable method to cover the expenses of a birth doula? Although insurance companies do not explicitly provide coverage for birth doula services, it is possible to allocate HSA or FSA funds for this purpose, according to the regulations laid out by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).

As per the IRS regulations, this is permissible when your physician attests that such care is medically necessary for the treatment of a specific medical condition, such as pregnancy. To seek reimbursement from your HSA or FSA, you would need to follow these essential steps:

  1. Settle the doula fee in its entirety and obtain a detailed invoice that outlines the services rendered along with the associated costs. *Note: Cliffrose Doula Care provides proper invoices for all of our birth clientele.
  2. Complete a Letter of Medical Necessity form, which can be procured from your insurance provider or a generic one can be used. Here is an example.
  3. Secure the signature of your medical provider, such as your obstetrician (OB) or midwife, on the form, affirming the medical condition of pregnancy.
  4. Submit the invoice and Letter of Medical Necessity form to your HSA/FSA, usually through online means.

By embracing this option, you can effectively make doula care more economically viable and accessible.

However, if this option is not available to you, it is advisable to have an open conversation with us about the possibility of establishing a payment plan to ease the financial burden.

Nonetheless, it is important to bear in mind that the numerous benefits of doula care, including personalized prenatal education, reduction in medical interventions, diminished reliance on pain medication, and decreased likelihood of cesarean sections, often culminate in a more cost-effective birthing experience overall (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, 2020; DONA International, 2021).
